natural problem:
Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
natural solution: Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]

There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
shows  "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
shows  "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the number of distinguishable ways to arrange 8 objects. The final answer is 1680.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "distinguishable_ways n = fact n div 48"
shows  "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "distinguishable_ways n = fact n div 48"
shows  "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the number of distinguishable ways to arrange 8 objects, given that the number of ways is equal to the factorial of 8 divided by 48. The final answer is 1,680.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes octahedron_construct :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> f. (\<forall> i \<in> {1..8}. f i \<in> {1..8} \<and> f i \<noteq> f (i + 1)) \<longrightarrow> octahedron_construct f = 1680"
shows  "octahedron_construct (\<lambda> i. if i \<in> {1..8} then i else 0) = 1680"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes octahedron_construct :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> f. (\<forall> i \<in> {1..8}. f i \<in> {1..8} \<and> f i \<noteq> f (i + 1)) \<longrightarrow> octahedron_construct f = 1680"
shows  "octahedron_construct (\<lambda> i. if i \<in> {1..8} then i else 0) = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A function `octahedron_construct` takes as input another function `f` that maps numbers from 1 to 8 to numbers from 1 to 8 such that no two consecutive numbers have the same image under `f`. Prove that for all such functions `f`, `octahedron_construct(f)` is equal to 1680. Furthermore, show that `octahedron_construct` applied to the function `g` that maps any number `i` from 1 to 8 to itself and maps any other number to 0 also results in 1680.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distinguishable_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinguishable_ways = card {O | O. regular_octahedron_with_distinct_colors O}"
shows  "distinguishable_ways = 1680"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes distinguishable_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinguishable_ways = card {O | O. regular_octahedron_with_distinct_colors O}"
shows  "distinguishable_ways = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the number of distinguishable ways to color a regular octahedron with distinct colors. The final answer is 1680.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "ways = card {octahedron :: (nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. distinct_colors octahedron}"
and h1 : "distinct_colors (a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h) = (a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> a \<noteq> e \<and> a \<noteq> f \<and> a \<noteq> g \<and> a \<noteq> h \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> e \<and> b \<noteq> f \<and> b \<noteq> g \<and> b \<noteq> h \<and> c \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> e \<and> c \<noteq> f \<and> c \<noteq> g \<and> c \<noteq> h \<and> d \<noteq> e \<and> d \<noteq> f \<and> d \<noteq> g \<and> d \<noteq> h \<and> e \<noteq> f \<and> e \<noteq> g \<and> e \<noteq> h \<and> f \<noteq> g \<and> f \<noteq> h \<and> g \<noteq> h)"
shows  "ways = 1680"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "ways = card {octahedron :: (nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat, nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. distinct_colors octahedron}"
and h1 : "distinct_colors (a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h) = (a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> d \<and> a \<noteq> e \<and> a \<noteq> f \<and> a \<noteq> g \<and> a \<noteq> h \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> d \<and> b \<noteq> e \<and> b \<noteq> f \<and> b \<noteq> g \<and> b \<noteq> h \<and> c \<noteq> d \<and> c \<noteq> e \<and> c \<noteq> f \<and> c \<noteq> g \<and> c \<noteq> h \<and> d \<noteq> e \<and> d \<noteq> f \<and> d \<noteq> g \<and> d \<noteq> h \<and> e \<noteq> f \<and> e \<noteq> g \<and> e \<noteq> h \<and> f \<noteq> g \<and> f \<noteq> h \<and> g \<noteq> h)"
shows  "ways = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many distinct ways can you color an octahedron with 8 colors such that no two adjacent faces have the same color? The final answer is 1680.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem octahedron_construction:
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "card {O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, O7, O8} = n"
and h2 : "distinct [O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, O7, O8]"
shows  "card {O | O. regular_octahedron O \<and> colorable O} = 1680"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem octahedron_construction:
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "card {O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, O7, O8} = n"
and h2 : "distinct [O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, O7, O8]"
shows  "card {O | O. regular_octahedron O \<and> colorable O} = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that there are 8 distinct octahedra labeled O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, O7, and O8, find the number of ways to create a regular octahedron and color it such that it is colorable. The final answer is 1680.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n d n_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "d = 3"
and h2 : "n_ways = fact n div (fact (n div d)) powr d"
shows  "n_ways = 1680"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes n d n_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "d = 3"
and h2 : "n_ways = fact n div (fact (n div d)) powr d"
shows  "n_ways = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In how many ways can 8 identical objects be divided into 3 equal parts? The final answer is 1680.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distinguishable_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinguishable_ways = number_of_ways_to_construct_regular_octahedron 8"
shows  "distinguishable_ways = 1680"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes distinguishable_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinguishable_ways = number_of_ways_to_construct_regular_octahedron 8"
shows  "distinguishable_ways = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many distinguishable ways are there to construct a regular octahedron with 8 vertices? The final answer is 1680.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = card {octahedron :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. (\<forall> triangle_color. (\<exists>! triangle. triangle_color triangle = triangle_color)) \<and> (\<forall> triangle1 triangle2. triangle_color triangle1 \<noteq> triangle_color triangle2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>! rotation. triangle_color (rotation triangle1) = triangle_color triangle2))}"
shows  "n = 1680"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = card {octahedron :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. (\<forall> triangle_color. (\<exists>! triangle. triangle_color triangle = triangle_color)) \<and> (\<forall> triangle1 triangle2. triangle_color triangle1 \<noteq> triangle_color triangle2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>! rotation. triangle_color (rotation triangle1) = triangle_color triangle2))}"
shows  "n = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider an octahedron with each of its 8 triangular faces colored in such a way that, for any two triangles with different colors, there is a unique rotation of the octahedron that maps one triangle to the other. How many distinct colorings of the octahedron are there? The final answer is 1680.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
shows  "distinguishable_ways 8 = 1680"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Eight congruent equilateral triangles, each of a different color, are used to construct a regular octahedron. How many distinguishable ways are there to construct the octahedron? (Two colored octahedrons are distinguishable if neither can be rotated to look just like the other.)
[asy] import three; import math; unitsize(1.5cm); currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1);  triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); [/asy]
$\textbf {(A)}\ 210 \qquad \textbf {(B)}\ 560 \qquad \textbf {(C)}\ 840 \qquad \textbf {(D)}\ 1260 \qquad \textbf {(E)}\ 1680$
 The final Answer is 1680
 ### Proof
 Since the octahedron is indistinguishable by rotations, without loss of generality fix a face to be red. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0.2,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); draw(A--B--E--cycle); draw(A--C--D--cycle); draw(F--C--B--cycle); draw(F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight);[/asy]
 There are $7!$ ways to arrange the remaining seven colors, but there still are three possible rotations about the fixed face, so the answer is $7!/3 = \boxed{1680}$. [asy] size(8cm); defaultpen(0.5); import three; import math; currentprojection=orthographic(2,0,1); triple A=(0,0,1); triple B=(sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple C=(sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple D=(-sqrt(2)/2,-sqrt(2)/2,0); triple E=(-sqrt(2)/2,sqrt(2)/2,0); triple F=(0,0,-1); triple right=(0,1,0); picture p = new picture, r = new picture, s = new picture; draw(p,A--B--E--cycle); draw(p,A--C--D--cycle); draw(p,F--C--B--cycle); draw(p,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(p,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(p,surface(A--B--E--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*p); draw(r,A--B--E--cycle); draw(r,A--C--D--cycle); draw(r,F--C--B--cycle); draw(r,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(r,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(r,surface(A--C--D--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(2*right)*r); draw(s,A--B--E--cycle); draw(s,A--C--D--cycle); draw(s,F--C--B--cycle); draw(s,F--D--E--cycle,dotted+linewidth(0.7)); draw(s,surface(A--B--C--cycle),rgb(1,.6,.6),nolight); draw(s,surface(B--C--F--cycle),rgb(1,1,.6),nolight); add(scale3(2.2)*shift(4*right)*s); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "distinguishable_ways n = 1680"
shows  "distinguishable_ways 8 = 1680"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In how many distinguishable ways can 8 objects be arranged? The final answer is 1680.
